>> STRICKER: Good morning. Hi. Wow, you like
that entertainment. Goodness. I'm Gabriel

9.text:
Stricker, Director of Global Communications
and Public Affairs at Google. I just have

13.text:
a couple of quick housekeeping items to go
through before we begin. First, is everyone

18.text:
able to access the Wi-Fi in here? I'm actually--I'm
getting some yes and no. So, the networks

26.text:
are Search On 1 through Search On 5, so not
the SFMOMA network. And the password is--is

32.text:
isearchongoog. The letter "I" search on goog
is the password. So, Search On 1 through Search

42.text:
On 5. isearchongoog is the password. For those
of you who are not here, who are viewing this

49.text:
via our streaming, we're going to have a Q&A
at the end of the presentation, and you guys

56.text:
can submit questions for us via the email
alias search2010@google.com. So that's search

64.text:
2-0-1-0 at google.com. And then for those
of you who are here, we're going to have some

70.text:
demos at the--at the end of today's presentation
as well, so just stick around and you guys

75.text:
will be able to walk through a lot of what
we're going to be announcing today. So with

81.text:
that, I just wanted to give you a quick sort
of update on why it is that we're here. So,

88.text:
periodically we do these State of the Unions
really for two reasons. First is we hear from

93.text:
a lot of you that with the kind breakneck
pace of innovation that we go through at Google,

97.text:
it's nice for us to kind of let you catch
your breath and give you a sense of where

102.text:
we are and where we're going, and so we'll
do some of that. And then secondly, we hear

106.text:
that it's helpful from time to time to kind
of take a look under the hood and get a sense

111.text:
of the anatomy of what we do and why and how,
and so you'll certainly hear a lot about that

116.text:
as well. So, here we are at the SFMOMA, and,
you know, what we do at Google, and in Search

126.text:
in particular, is really one part art and
one part science. We're here at the SFMOMA

132.text:
today in recognition of the art part of that
equation. The science, well, you're going

137.text:
to hear from our Search rocket scientists
in a second who will hold your hand through

141.text:
the latest and greatest of what we're up to.
But before we go there, I just wanted to flag

146.text:
one thing, and some of you may have heard
some of--of the remarks from Eric Schmidt,

151.text:
Google's CEO, yesterday in Berlin. And there
he said, "Never underestimate the importance

159.text:
of fast." Today, we're going to be talking
a lot about speed and the importance of fast.

166.text:
And in recognition of that and in an attempt
to kind of keep things moving on time, I'm

172.text:
going to hand it over to our Vice President
of Search Products and User Experience, Marissa

177.text:
Mayer. Thank you. [pause]
>> MAYER: Thank you, Gabriel. Good morning

186.text:
and welcome, and thanks to all of you for
coming to our Search event this morning. Obviously,

191.text:
we have a really big announcement. But before
we get to the announcement, I thought I would

195.text:
offer some insight into just how far Search
has already come in 2010, starting with an

202.text:
exciting stat. In the past few months, we've
crossed the "One Billion Users On Google's

209.text:
Site Each Week" mark. We're really excited
about this. We couldn't have done this without

213.text:
our users, and we're profoundly grateful to
them. And we want to really renew our commitment

219.text:
to constantly be improving our quality and
constantly improving our user experience.

224.text:
This statistic makes Google Search one of
the most used services. Not only internet

229.text:
services, but services all over the world,
and we're really excited and honored to have

234.text:
achieved this milestone. And we couldn't have
done it without our users. We also couldn't

238.text:
have done it without a constant innovation
and a constant sense of improvement. Most

243.text:
of you know that we actually roll out hundreds
of changes each year. In 2009, for example,

248.text:
we rolled out more than 500 UI and ranking
changes to Google Search. Already in 2010,

256.text:
we've already rolled out more than 500 changes
to our ranking and to our UI. And so this

263.text:
stands to be the best year ever for Google
Search. We've already had hundreds of improvements

269.text:
in 2010, and I thought I would highlight just
a few of them. First up, we have Caffeine,

276.text:
our new indexing system, which makes our index
50% fresher. This ultimately means that our

283.text:
users get much more up-to-date and timely
results, and we can find the best information

288.text:
regardless of where it is and when it was
written. It really helps our index to be fast.

295.text:
We also rolled out Real-Time at the tail end
of 2009, but that hasn't stopped us in 2010

301.text:
from continuing to build advances. We've been
working on our triggering, so when Real-Time

306.text:
shows up in our search results, it's incredibly
relevant. We've also just rolled out a whole

311.text:
slew of features, including timeline views
and conversation views. We're really excited

316.text:
about how to show real-time information, tweets
and updates in the context of Search to really

322.text:
help our users understand what's going on.
We've also been making improvements to our

328.text:
spell corrections. That may seem funny, because
we've had spell correction for a number of

332.text:
years now, but in the past year, we've actually
made it much easier for our users to find

339.text:
the spell corrections, because we now offer
them as part of the auto complete. You now

343.text:
get spell corrections before you even do your
search. They show up there right underneath

347.text:
the search box. We've also made great strides
in how to handle proper nouns and really do

352.text:
complicated spelling corrections. We've also
rolled out enhancements to our Questions & Answers.

360.text:
Two years ago in 2008, at an event much like
this, we rolled out a product called Google

364.text:
Squared, which was a technology demonstration
that showed how we could intuit facts from

369.text:
the data on the web. We've taken the technology
behind Google Squared and launched it as part

375.text:
of our core web search. So today, you can
type small questions or facts into Google

381.text:
Search and get answer right on the top of
the Results page. Like the inventor of the

385.text:
telephone. It just says Alexander Graham Bell.
And it also works for real-time events as

391.text:
well and current events. You can type things
like "Iron Man 2 release date" and it'll give

396.text:
the release date right on top of the Search
Results page. And we've also rolled out Stars

402.text:
in Search. We're constantly working to make
Google Search more personalized. And through

406.text:
our experiments with products like Search
Wiki, what we found was that users really

410.text:
wanted to be able to bookmark results. To
say, "This URL I want at the top of this search

416.text:
in the future and any related search, and
I also want a way to be able to get back to

419.text:
it easily." We now have Stars in Search rolled
out on all users who are signed in for all

426.text:
their searches and with a Star accompanying
each search result, so it's always easy to

430.text:
bookmark a result and be able to come back
to it. And finally, in April we rolled out

435.text:
our redesign. Our redesign introduced a left
hand navigation panel that has all kinds of

441.text:
dynamic tools that'll help our users slice
and dice their--their results in entirely

445.text:
new ways, ultimately helping them find what
they're looking for all that much faster.

450.text:
We also redid the formatting of the main Search
Results in order to help our users scan and

455.text:
find what they were looking for that much
faster. And through all of these improvements,

460.text:
we've also managed to have a little bit of
fun. So, in January, we had our first television

465.text:
commercial, a Super Bowl commercial, no less,
featuring Search. Let's go ahead and roll

477.text:
>> Hello. Bon jour.
>> Tu es tres mignon. [pause]

522.text:
>> And the fun didn't stop there. We actually
renamed ourselves Topeka for April Fool's

526.text:
in honor of Topeka, Kansas, which named themselves
Google for our Fiber-to-the-Home project.

531.text:
And over the past few days, we've been having
fun with our logos. So many of you probably

536.text:
saw yesterday the bubble logo that was on
our web site. How many people played with

540.text:
it? It's pretty fun. It's almost like a digital
Zen garden, which is very relaxing to see--see

546.text:
the bubbles sort of explode all over the screen.
But we really ran this logo because we want

551.text:
Search to be fun, fast, and interactive. And
this doodle was designed to tease our announcement

555.text:
today. And then last night we lead with yet
another doodle that helped illustrate and

561.text:
give even more of a clue of what we're doing
in that it lit up as your typed into the search

566.text:
box. So this was a little bit of fun to get
people in the mood for today's announcement.

573.text:
And today's announcement does represent what
we believe is a fundamental shift to Search.

577.text:
How people think about Search. How people
do Search. The speed and ease with which people

582.text:
can find information. And as such, and to
put today's announcement in perspective, I

587.text:
thought I should offer some insight into the
evolution of how people find information.

593.text:
We're here today at the MOMA. The MOMA has
an amazing permanent collection, and one of

598.text:
the most important pieces in it is Woman with
a Hat by Henri Matisse. Woman with a Hat was

603.text:
painted in 1905. It actually is Matisse's
wife, Amelie. When she posed for the painting,

610.text:
she was actually dressed entirely in black.
A black dress and a black hat. And as Matisse

617.text:
painted this painting, a new art movement
was born called Fauvism, where the focus is

622.text:
on painterly technique and the use of bright
colors even when bright colors don't appear

626.text:
in the subject. It's a very important piece.
It's a very special piece that the MOMA has

631.text:
here on site. But if you wanted to be able
to find out all of the information and trivia

636.text:
that I just rattled off about--about Woman
with a Hat, say, 75 years ago when the MOMA

642.text:
first opened in 1935, you would've probably
had to have spend half a day to a day in a

649.text:
library. You would've physically had to have
gone to the library. You would've had to find

653.text:
references to the painting. You would've had
to stitch together all of these different

657.text:
facts to really understand what was happening
with this painting. If you move forward to

663.text:
1950, things get a little bit faster, mostly
because of the prevalence of telephones. With

669.text:
the telephone, you could basically skip the
step of actually going to the library. You

673.text:
could call a librarian. You'd still have to
verify that you were talking about the right

676.text:
painting and getting the right information,
but you could get the information probably

680.text:
in, say, about half an hour. Fast forward
to 1995. Here personal computers come into

687.text:
play. There were CD-ROM-based encyclopedias,
and as long as your encyclopedia had an entry

692.text:
for Woman with a Hat, you could find this
information probably in the matter--in a matter

697.text:
of minutes. But the problem with that is that
it was static information. It didn't really

702.text:
tell you is the piece on display right now?
You know, is it on tour? Where is the piece?

708.text:
This is my favorite piece in the San Francisco
MOMA's permanent collection. It's Roy Lichtenstein's

713.text:
Mirror #1. And I come here often to see it.
And I will say that sometimes it's here, and

718.text:
sometimes it's not. And it's really hard to
tell when it's going to be here or not. But

724.text:
when you look at Search and how it plays out
today, this is where the power of the internet

728.text:
really comes into play, because you can have
real-time information. So, for example, if

732.text:
you search for "Lichtenstein mirror SFMOMA,"
in the snippets you can actually see that

738.text:
the mirror in on display in the second floor,
and if it's on tour, it notes it on the web

742.text:
page. This is something that's really wonderful,
and it actually has taken search time from

746.text:
that half a day to a day that we saw in 1935
to about half a minute. But let's go ahead

752.text:
and take a look at where time is really spent
in a search. We know that it takes a user

758.text:
on average about nine seconds to enter their
search into Google. After they hit the Search

764.text:
button, it comes to us. There's some network
time. Spends about 300 milliseconds on our

770.text:
servers on average. Goes back over the network.
And then after it renders on their page, they

776.text:
spend about 15 seconds on average picking
the right result for them. As you can imagine,

783.text:
because we are so focused on speed--never
underestimate fast--we have spent a lot of

788.text:
time optimizing the 300 milliseconds when
the search is on our servers. Making our algorithms

794.text:
more efficient. Making our computers more
efficient. Really trying to makes sure that

799.text:
we have Search as fast and as efficient as
absolutely possible while it's on our servers.

804.text:
We've also spent some time thinking about
network time. This is what our Fiber-to-the-Home

810.text:
project is about; helping people understand
how fast their connection could be, how fast

814.text:
it should be and really pushing on this. Also
we have tools like Google Chrome, which really

820.text:
don't focus on network time but do focus on
rendering time and other overhead in the browser

825.text:
to really try and make people's experience
with the internet as fast and clean as possible.

831.text:
But despite all that emphasis on optimizing,
you might say, "Well, a search takes 25 seconds,

837.text:
and all of that focus is really on only one
of the 25 seconds." Of course, there's 24

842.text:
other seconds of typing and thinking that
a user really spends. And you might say, "Well,

848.text:
but is it possible to even optimize that?"
And in truth, we actually have tried to optimize

853.text:
it. For entering a query, we've added features
to our search engine like auto complete, so

858.text:
when you're typing a query, popular completions
show up right there so you can do less typing

862.text:
and enter your search faster. On selecting
a result, we'll do things like the Google

867.text:
redesign to help people scan the page and
find information even faster because of the

874.text:
overall layout. But you may realize that at
some point we're really up against the fact

879.text:
that entering a query, there's a physical
speed for typing, and in terms of selecting

884.text:
a result, there's a physical speed for thinking.
And this is where we really say, you know,

891.text:
can we optimize Search even more? Is it possible
to make it even faster? And in the past few

897.text:
months at Google, we've had a key insight.
We think it is possible. We think it's possible

901.text:
to have a system that provides a user with
an easier way to enter a query with a lot

906.text:
of feedback, and ultimately make Search very,
very efficient. And we call that product Google

913.text:
Instant. And that's what we're launching today.
So, Google Instant actually gets queries and

921.text:
gets your search results as you type and brings
them to you and streams those results right

927.text:
to your computer, so the search is entirely
interactive the whole time you're typing.

931.text:
And because it's so interactive, we really
do need to show a demo. So I'm going to go

936.text:
over to the demo computer, and I have Dan
here, who's going to take a picture--we have

942.text:
a picture-in-picture that'll show up here
in a second, uh, so you can actually see what

946.text:
I'm typing and what actually happens onscreen.
So, let's go back to the Woman with a Hat.

953.text:
Let's say we couldn't remember the specific
name of this painting, and we just remembered

958.text:
there's an important painting at the SFMOMA.
It has a woman in it. You know, how does Google

963.text:
Instant work? Well, the first thing you'll
see if that Google Instant, it just is--it

967.text:
is and looks like the main Search Results
page--the main home page that you've always

971.text:
been accustomed to. So if I go ahead and start
typing my query and type S-F-M you'll see

979.text:
I did not hit return, and the results for
S-F-M, and actually for SFMOMA, because that's

985.text:
the predicted--the predicted query, are already
on the page. So with just three keystrokes,

992.text:
we actually already have the result for the
San Francisco MOMA. If I say, okay, that's

997.text:
great. I typed S-F-M. The prediction of SFMOMA
is right. I'll go ahead and tab, and then

1003.text:
I'll just type "woman" to try and find the
name of the painting. And again, just six

1007.text:
keystrokes later, we already know that, in
fact, the painting is called Femme au chapeau,

1014.text:
Woman with a Hat. So it's just that fast and
that interactive. The results with each keystroke.

1021.text:
No hitting the Search button. No hitting Return.
The results just stream to you based on the

1026.text:
predictions that are most likely, uh, given
your--given what you've typed so far. So let's

1032.text:
go ahead and actually do a look up on the
formal name of the painting, which is French.

1037.text:
Femme au chapeau. If I type "femme au", what
you'll see here is that the most likely completion

1045.text:
is a Picasso painting, Woman with Crossed
Arms. But you can also see five other searches

1051.text:
here right below the search box. And I can
do those searches by simply using my up and

1057.text:
down arrow keys. So you'll note here that
all I do is press down. Does that search.

1063.text:
"Women with chocolate." Uh, and then you can
keep going through the search results and

1068.text:
they just update. So as you scroll up and
down the overall recommendations and predictions,

1075.text:
you can see the results right there. No more
typing. You can explore the whole space of

1081.text:
your query, Femme au chapeau, and all of the
related queries. Let's go ahead and take a

1088.text:
lot at Fauvism. Fauvism is the painting movement
that actually came into play with Woman with

1095.text:
a Hat. And if we type "Fauvism", what you'll
see is--if I type F-A-U-V, it's already figured

1102.text:
out that I'm likely to type Fauvism. So with
just four characters, I already have a definition

1107.text:
of Fauvism, pictures and paintings that show
examples of it, mm-hmm. And you'll note that

1113.text:
a lot of people think Google Instant is search
as you type, but it's actually search before

1119.text:
you type. We didn't do a search for F-A-U-V.
We did a search for Fauvism, because that

1125.text:
was the most likely completion. So we're actually
predicting what query you're likely to do

1131.text:
and giving you results for that. We think
this ultimately results in a much higher quality

1135.text:
experience, but there's even a psychic element
of it in that we can actually predict what

1141.text:
you're likely to type and bring you those
results in real time. And the other cool thing

1146.text:
is using the predictions, you can build--you
can build your query much more easily. So

1150.text:
let's go back to the Lichtenstein mirror.
If I type Lichtenstein. L-I-C-H-T. Google's

1156.text:
already figured out that I'm likely to type
Lichtenstein. Doesn't know is it the artist

1161.text:
or the country, but I can hit Tab, then type
M-I for "mirror", and again, it's already

1166.text:
figured out that I'm likely to type mirror.
Hit Tab. Hit S-F. And there's the page on

1173.text:
the Lichtenstein mirror here at the MOMA.
We're really excited about what Google Instant

1180.text:
means in terms of Search. It means much faster
Search, easier Search, an easier way to explore

1185.text:
all of the related queries around the query
that you're doing, and really providing results

1192.text:
in real time before you've even had the--had
the opportunity to type your query. We're

1197.text:
really ultimately excited about this. Let's
go ahead and go back to slide. This is funny.

1204.text:
This is something that I don't know if many
of you have seen, but in 2000, we actually

1209.text:
thought that this idea of being able to search
before someone typed was so far out it was

1215.text:
actually our April Fool's Day joke. I was
called MentalPlex, and it says, be sure to

1220.text:
remove your hat and glasses. Look into the
circle. Think about what you want to search

1225.text:
and present it. And so we thought this was
sort of a fun--fun bit of Google history,

1230.text:
and that obviously dovetails with today, because
just ten years later, what we're seeing is

1235.text:
it's actually possible for us to greatly ease
the entering of a query, greatly ease the

1241.text:
scanning of results, and really speed up the
Google Search experience. Google Instant is

1248.text:
going to be--is going to be available later
today on a variety of browsers. It'll be available

1254.text:
on Google Chrome, on Firefox, on Safari and
on IE8. Mm-hmm. And this will all be rolling

1264.text:
out over the course of today. So starting
today, if you're using one of those browsers,

1269.text:
you will be getting Google Instant as part
of your core web search experience. We'll

1275.text:
be rolling this out as part of our home page
and on google.com in the U.S. But over the

1280.text:
next week, we'll also be rolling this out
internationally. In the U.K., in France, in

1287.text:
Italy, in Germany, in Spain, and in Russia
for all users who are signed in. So if you're

1296.text:
signed in and you're using one of those country
sites, you'll also be able to experience Google

1301.text:
Instant within the week. We're really excited
about what Google Instant could mean, in terms

1307.text:
of the evolution of Search and the future
of Search and what it means in terms of how

1312.text:
it will change people ultimately searching.
In fact, we estimate that Google Instant will

1317.text:
help our users save two to five seconds per
query. That may not seem like a lot, but when

1322.text:
you add that to the billion searches and more
a day that come--a week that come to Google,

1329.text:
you actually get significant savings. In fact,
you actually will be able to save 11 hours

1336.text:
for every passing second. We're really--again,
we couldn't be more pleased with how this

1342.text:
product has developed, and I'm really excited
to introduce to you the team that built Google

1348.text:
Instant, so they can talk to you about some
of the technical challenges and some of the

1352.text:
product challenges that came about in building
Google Instant and what it ultimately means.

1357.text:
With that, I'd like to welcome Othar Hansson
and Johanna Wright to the stage. [pause]

1365.text:
>> WRIGHT: Imagine if Google were even faster
than it was before, if it knew and understood

1375.text:
just what you were trying to say before you
finished typing, if it could give you feedback

1381.text:
as you went along to get you better results.
Well, that's what we're here to talk about

1387.text:
today. We've been using Google Instant for
months, and we want to talk about how it's

1393.text:
gonna revolutionize the way that we interact--all
of us interact with a search engine. This

1399.text:
is not a screen-shot story. You truly have
to experience Google Instant yourself to understand

1406.text:
its power. We're gonna do the best we can
with our demos, but please check out the demo

1410.text:
stations on your way out, and today, please
use Google as Instant rolls out to our servers.

1417.text:
I'm Johanna Wright. I'm the Director of Product
Management on Search and working on Google

1421.text:
Instant.
>> HANSSON: And I'm Othar, the engineering

1423.text:
lead on Google Instant. Today we're making
Google Search faster and easier than ever

1427.text:
before, and Johanna and I are excited to show
you the three main features that you'll start

1432.text:
noticing today.
>> WRIGHT: And you can think of these three

1435.text:
features like gears in a system. One small
change in one gear can have vast leverage

1442.text:
over the full system, making your search much
more efficient. In Google Instant, the first

1450.text:
gear is Instant Results. The second is our
set of Predictions. And the third is what

1460.text:
we call "Scroll to Search." Let's jump in,
and let's start by taking a look at Instant

1468.text:
Results. Immediately when you start typing,
results display on the screen instantly. There's

1474.text:
no need to finish typing. There's no need
to hit Enter. Um, I'm actually a little sad

1482.text:
that the summer is over. It's hard to believe
that Labor Day Weekend was just last weekend,

1486.text:
and, um, now it's fall. And, Othar, we're
here in San Francisco. Why don't you use Google

1491.text:
to check out the weather?
>> HANSSON: Sure. This is a great search for

1494.text:
Google Instant, because with exactly one key
press, on W, I can get a weather forecast

1499.text:
for San Francisco. Whoo! 60 degrees. So, uh,
my career as a hand model means we can't show

1509.text:
my hand, but in slow motion, I'll use one
key press. Weather. I did not press the Search

1517.text:
button or press Enter. My fingers never left
my hands.

1520.text:
>> WRIGHT: So even in slow motion, Othar was
fast. And you can tell that he found out the

1526.text:
weather was 60 degrees out-- that's right,
60 degrees out by typing in just one keystroke.

1531.text:
So now that we've talked about the first gear,
Instant Results, let's move on to the second--

1537.text:
Predictions. This summer, I, and maybe many
of you in this room, read the book "The Girl

1542.text:
with the Dragon Tattoo." I don't think Othar
read it. He's making fun of me there.

detect when the experience was broken. You

2788.text:
might go from one cafe to another, and the
internet speed, you know, drops dramatically.

So we wanna detect that and proactively opt
you out of the experience and give you a little

2798.text:

happened. When you go back to the other cafe,

2802.text:

summary of the application.

>> GOMES: So now we come to the third part

2813.text:

2817.text:
the problem. We want to give you search results
with every letter. An average query's about

2822.text:
20 letters long. So if we give you search
results with every character, that's 20 queries

2827.text:
for every search you do. So we got this--I
got this response every time we demoed this

plan in the world where we want--we're already

2839.text:

unless people from other planets suddenly

2848.text:

plan for like 20 times--20--a factor of 20

2853.text:
growth in Search traffic? So this was one
of the most interesting challenges in getting

2858.text:
this down to something practical that we could
actually do.

2861.text:
>> HANSSON: Thankfully, Google has thousands
of engineers who love challenges like this,

2867.text:
many of them in our Search infrastructure
group. And they came to us at first skeptical.

2872.text:
They would say things like, "You're never
gonna launch this." But I realized last night

2875.text:
while running a load test that if you did
this and that, you could save 27%, and here's

2880.text:
a simulator that, you know, shows you how
to do it. And then someone else would say,

2884.text:
I realize that if you just made this optimization
here, you could probably save another 12%.

2889.text:
And if enough of these skeptical, helpful
people come together, you get enough optimizations

2894.text:
to get to the finish line. So let's just look
at a couple of these optimizations. So the

2898.text:
first was realizing that some searches are
more important than others, where more confidence

2903.text:
given, you know, like a single letter that--in
some predictions than in others. So we wanna

2909.text:
make sure we serve those results to you as
fast as possible. And that, you know, by prioritizing

2914.text:
searches differently, we can reduce the average
cost per search and the number of searches

2918.text:
we do. The next optimization is this thing
we alluded to before in the client/server

2923.text:
aspect--that if the servers can keep track
of what the browser either already has or

2928.text:
what's already in progress for them on some
other server, then we don't have to do needless

2933.text:
work. We can, uh, reduce the number of searches
that way. A final and pretty sophisticated

2939.text:
improvement we made was in our caching system.
So caching is always a tension for Google

2944.text:
because we want our results to be as fresh
as possible as we crawl and index the web.

2948.text:
But we also want them to be cached so we can
serve them to users as quickly as possible.

2954.text:
So this was one of, you know, the most sophisticated
things we built. There was already a team

2958.text:
working on it, and we accelerated that effort
tremendously. So we have, you know, very sophisticated

2964.text:
caching in all our backends and many more
optimizations to get us to the finish line

2970.text:
and be able to launch today.

the heart of our human curiosity of our need

believe it matters to people. It matters to

3043.text:
us. Getting people to the information they
need quickly and efficiently matters in their

3050.text:
lives. It helps them make better decisions.
It helps them enrich their lives...from the

3054.text:
patient looking to understand his treatment
to the teacher looking for materials to inspire

3059.text:
her students. To the journalist looking to
investigate a new story--it matters. So we're

last year alone, we launched over 500 changes

3070.text:

your search experience...from a much bigger

3098.text:

to the version you see today, I feel sure

3104.text:
that this is the future direction of Search.
Not only does it make Search faster--that's

3109.text:

more fun, fluid, and interactive. It enables

3116.text:
you to formulate better queries with the results

3121.text:

3127.text:

3131.text:

3137.text:
